Poetry of the War," attracted a
TENTH SESSION

holder of the Congressional Medal
July 6th - August 13th, 1920
for bravery under fire while captain with the Three Hundred and
Seventh Infantry, Dr. Miles was
well qualified to speak upon this
subject.

Following the reading of the'
papers the election of officers for
the coming year was held. George
Mathematics
Goetz was re-elected president;
Reuben Foster, vice-president;
Philosophy
Fulton Bramble treasurer, and

On Saturday evening a dinner
was held at the Hopkins Club.
There were numerous toasts and
Psychology
speeches and much conviviality
prevailed. The club had as its
Spanish
guests, Prof. Alfred Breit and
Captain Du Pont. Professor
Breit, who is instructor in Russian at the University, spoke on
"Russian Literature." "French
Life" was the subject of Captain
Du Pont's talk. He made the con- For further information, see

students were much too quiet.
The Penn Relays, held at Philadelphia recently, proved to be the
most sensational seen in many
years. Many collegiate records
were broken, and in the principal
event of the carnival, the two-mile
relay, the Oxford-Cambridge team
lowered the world's record 25s
seconds, crossing the finish about
40 yards in advance of our best
entry, Illinois.

The sophomores easily defeated
the freshmen in the annual base
ball game last Thursday oil

and devoid of thrills, except when
"Andy" Knecht lifted the ball
over the fence into Universiiy
Parkway for a home run in the
first inning. "Andy" kept up the
good work during the rest of the
game by getting four hits out 4d
four times up.
A. H. Smith was on the mound
for '23 and did very creditable
work by punching out seven men.
although .he allowed 10 hits. Le
yin, behind the bat, was all th:i
was needed in the way of a backstop. The sophomores were fortunate in having a 'Varsity battery, Williams and Wood, the former striking out nine men and
allowing only five hits. These
two men were also credited with
a three-base hit apiece.

Mass-meeting Friday.

A niassmeeting will be held on
Friday, May 28, for the purpose of
arousing enthusiasm for the coming games with Lehigh and Maryland State. Various members of
the teams will make addresses. It
is also likely that the Student
Council for next year will make
some announcements.
At the same meeting, the petition which was printed in last
week's NEWS-LETTER will be presented to the student body. The
only change made is in the suggested apportionment of the fee.
This, as it now reads, gives THE
NEWS LETTER $2 and
the Y. M. C.
A. $1. The other allotments remain unchanged, thus leaving a
balance of 50 cents from each fee,
which would be about $300 in all
to be held in reserve. As has been
pointed out before, the proposed
apportionment is merely a suggestion, and the final decision will
be made by the 'Varsity Seal Voting Council, subject to the approval of the chairman of the Student Affairs Committee.

Last Thursday a meeting of exservice men was arranged by Dr.
R. V. H. Magoffin for the purpose
of organizing a Post of the American Legion at Johns Hopkins.
After reading a list containing
the names of 35 men who had already signified their intention of
joining the post, he stated that
the officers of the post should be
elected immediately, so that an efficient organization might be developed before the end of the college year.
The election resulted as follows: Post commander, Capt. A.
0. Ellis vice post commander,
Dean J. B. Whitehead; historian,
Capt. W. A. Weyforth; treasurer,
C. C. Marbury. Captain Ellis then
appointed Sergeant Grummand
post adjutant.

The meeting was then turned
over to the new post commander,
who outlined plans for increasing
the membership. Any man who
has drawn pay and received an
honorable discharge from the
Army, Navy, Marine Corps or certain special units (S. A. T. C.) is
eligible to membership. It is
hoped that all students who have
served in any of the above-mentioned units will avail themselves
of this opportunity. The principles for which the American
Legion stands are "Pure Americanism and Law and Order." The
post at Johns Hopkins is No.
87, of the State of Maryland,
its official name not having been
chosen as yet. However, it will
probably be called the Johns
Hopkins Post. Membership in the
post has been thrown open to all
men connected with Hopkins who
have been in the service, whether
they are alumni or undergraduates. This means that there should
be no difficulty in obtaining a personnel which will make it one of
the leading posts in this State.
An organization of Middlebury
alumni, called the "100 Freshmen
Men Club," has been started. Each
member agrees to endeavor to look
upon one freshman of the right
sort, send him to Middlebury and
take an interest in him after he
matriculates.

Defeat Them In Baseball By a Score
of 6-2—Game Was Well Played
But Devoid of Thrills.

The sophomores easily defeated
the freshmen in the annual base
ball game last Thursday oil
Homewood Field by the score of
6 to 2. The game was well played
and devoid of thrills, except when
"Andy" Knecht lifted the ball
over the fence into Universiiy
Parkway for a home run in the
first inning. "Andy" kept up the
good work during the rest of the
game by getting four hits out 4d
four times up.
A. H. Smith was on the mound
for '23 and did very creditable
work by punching out seven men.
although .he allowed 10 hits. Le
yin, behind the bat, was all th:i
was needed in the way of a backstop. The sophomores were fortunate in having a 'Varsity battery, Williams and Wood, the former striking out nine men and
allowing only five hits. These
two men were also credited with
a three-base hit apiece.

Mass-meeting Friday.

A niassmeeting will be held on
Friday, May 28, for the purpose of
arousing enthusiasm for the coming games with Lehigh and Maryland State. Various members of
the teams will make addresses. It
is also likely that the Student
Council for next year will make
some announcements.
At the same meeting, the petition which was printed in last
week's NEWS-LETTER will be presented to the student body. The
only change made is in the suggested apportionment of the fee.
This, as it now reads, gives THE
NEWS LETTER $2 and
the Y. M. C.
A. $1. The other allotments remain unchanged, thus leaving a
balance of 50 cents from each fee,
which would be about $300 in all
to be held in reserve. As has been
pointed out before, the proposed
apportionment is merely a suggestion, and the final decision will
be made by the 'Varsity Seal Voting Council, subject to the approval of the chairman of the Student Affairs Committee.

Last Thursday a meeting of exservice men was arranged by Dr.
R. V. H. Magoffin for the purpose
of organizing a Post of the American Legion at Johns Hopkins.
After reading a list containing
the names of 35 men who had already signified their intention of
joining the post, he stated that
the officers of the post should be
elected immediately, so that an efficient organization might be developed before the end of the college year.
The election resulted as follows: Post commander, Capt. A.
0. Ellis vice post commander,
Dean J. B. Whitehead; historian,
Capt. W. A. Weyforth; treasurer,
C. C. Marbury. Captain Ellis then
appointed Sergeant Grummand
post adjutant.

The meeting was then turned
over to the new post commander,
who outlined plans for increasing
the membership. Any man who
has drawn pay and received an
honorable discharge from the
Army, Navy, Marine Corps or certain special units (S. A. T. C.) is
eligible to membership. It is
hoped that all students who have
served in any of the above-mentioned units will avail themselves
of this opportunity. The principles for which the American
Legion stands are "Pure Americanism and Law and Order." The
post at Johns Hopkins is No.
87, of the State of Maryland,
its official name not having been
chosen as yet. However, it will
probably be called the Johns
Hopkins Post. Membership in the
post has been thrown open to all
men connected with Hopkins who
have been in the service, whether
they are alumni or undergraduates. This means that there should
be no difficulty in obtaining a personnel which will make it one of
the leading posts in this State.
An organization of Middlebury
alumni, called the "100 Freshmen
Men Club," has been started. Each
member agrees to endeavor to look
upon one freshman of the right
sort, send him to Middlebury and
take an interest in him after he
matriculates.
